case_name: M. M. Thammaiah and B. M. Kariappa v. State of Mysore and Divisional Forest Officer

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1721 of 1971 and Civil Appeal No. 1000 of 1972 are cross-appeals by certificate from the Mysore High Court judgment dated March 18, 1971 in Writ Petition 6394 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1721 of 1971 and 1000 of 1972. Appeals by certificate from the judgment and order dated the 18th March, 1971 of the Mysore High Court in W.P. 6394 of 1969.

facts.text: Civil Appeal 1000 of 1972 filed by M. M. Thammaiah and B. M. Kariappa against the State of Mysore and the Divisional Forest Officer, South Coorg Division, Hunsur.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal 1000 of 1972 is filed by two persons called M. M. Thammaiah and B. M. Kariappa  herein called the appellants , against the State of Mysore and the Divisional Forest Officer, South Coorg Division, Hunsur, Mysore  herein called the respondents .

facts.text: Civil Appeal 1721 of 1971 filed by the State of Mysore and the Divisional Forest Officer.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal 1721 of 1971 is filed by the State of Mysore and the Divisional Forest Officer.

facts.text: M. M. Thammaiah is the holder of immovable properties consisting partly of Bane lands situate at Nemmale in the district of Coorg.

anchor.surface_text: Appellant No. 1, M. M. Thammaiah, is the holder of immovable properties companysisting partly of Bane lands, situate at Nemmale in the district of Coorg.

facts.text: On October 17, 1968, M. M. Thammaiah sold certain soft-wood trees standing on his lands to B. M. Kariappa for Rs. 20,000.

anchor.surface_text: On October 17, 1968 he sold certain soft-wood trees standing on his lands to appellant 2 for a sum of Rs. 20,000.

facts.text: On September 23, 1969, M. M. Thammaiah applied to the Divisional Forest Officer for a permit in the name of B. M. Kariappa to cut and remove the timber.

anchor.surface_text: On September 23, 1969 he made an application to respondent 2, the Divisional Forest Officer, for the issue of a permit in the name of appellant No. 2 allowing him to cut and remove the timber.

facts.text: Divisional Forest Officer informed M. M. Thammaiah that the Bane lands were not redeemed and permission could not be granted unless timber value paid under Rule 137 of Mysore Forest Rules 1969.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent 2 informed appellant No. 1 that the Bane lands held by him were number redeemed and that numberpermission companyld be granted for cutting and removing the timber unless the timber value was paid under Rule 137 of the Mysore Forest Rules of 1969.

facts.text: Appellants filed Writ Petition in Mysore High Court under Article 226 challenging constitutionality of Rule 137 of Mysore Forest Rules.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by this order the appellant filed a petition in the High Court of Mysore under Article 226 of the Constitution challenging the companystitutionality of Rule 137 of the Mysore Forest Rules.

facts.text: Mysore High Court upheld validity of Rule 137 but held appellants liable to pay timber value only for trees existing at 1910 Survey Settlement.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Mysore upheld the validity of Rule 137 but it took the view that the appellants were liable to pay the timer value of only such trees as were in existence at the time of the. Survey Settlement of 1910.

facts.text: High Court directed forest authorities to determine trees existing in 1910 and permit after payment of their timber value.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court directed the forest authorities to determine which trees were in existence in 1910 and held that the appellants would be entitled to get the required permit after payment of the timber value of those trees.

facts.text: Appellants contend entitled to permit without any timber value payment.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the appellants is that they are entitled to the permit to cut and remove the timber without payment of any timber value at all

facts.text: State contends no distinction between trees of 1910 and later; liable for all timber value.

anchor.surface_text: while the companytention of the State Government is that numberdistinction can be made as between trees existing in 1910 and those which came into existence later

facts.text: Lands granted to M.M. Thammaiah by Raja of Coorg, situated in Nemmale village, Virajpet Taluk.

anchor.surface_text: The lands in question were granted to appellant No. 1 by the Raja of Coorg and are situated in the village of Nemmale, Virajpet Taluk,

facts.text: Summary settlement carried out in 1896 in Coorg.

anchor.surface_text: Years after Coorg came under the suzerainty of the British, a summary settlement was carried out in 1896 under the orders issued by the Chief Commissioner of Coorg.

facts.text: Coorg Land and Revenue Regulation came into force in 1899 (Regulation 1-A of 1899).

anchor.surface_text: The Coorg Land and Revenue Regulation came into force in 1899  Regulation 1-A of 1899 .

facts.text: Rule 97(1-A) of Coorg Land Revenue Rules: holder of Bane land who has not paid timber value enjoys personal usufruct for grant purpose; cannot cut/remove without permission and payment.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 97  1-A  of the Rules issued under the Coorg Land Revenue Rules provided, inter alia, that the holder of Bane land who has number paid,timber value when the grant was made would enjoy the personal usufruct of the trees growing upon the land for the purpose for which the grant was made.

facts.text: Bane lands allotted by Rajas for grazing, leaf manure, firewood for agricultural purposes per Warg.

anchor.surface_text: Explanation companytained in Chapter V of the Coorg Settlement Report, 1910 that a companysiderable area of forest lands which was deemed necessary for grazing and leaf manure and for providing firewood timber for agricultural purposes was allotted by the Rajas for each Warg.

facts.text: Survey settlement notification issued under Rule 49 of Regulation 1 of 1899 on October 9, 1906.

anchor.surface_text: On October 9, 1906 sanction was accorded by the Government for the resettlement of survey and a numberification was accordingly issued under Rule 49 of Regulation 1 of 1899.

facts.text: Coorg Settlement Report 1910 includes Rules for Classifiers in Appendix B.

anchor.surface_text: These Rules can be found in Appendix B to the letter dated February 18, 1910 written by Gustav Haller, Settlement Officer, Coorg, to the Secretary to the Chief Commissioner of Coorg.

facts.text: Rule 10 of Rules for Classifiers describes rights over unalienated banes, including exclusive right to cut for domestic/agricultural use without charge, but no right for sale without permission.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 10 The following terms are at present used for lands held for companyfee cultivation Unalienated banes  jama, sagu, jodi, jaghir, umbli  of which ten acres may be cultivated free of assessment.

facts.text: Coorg became part of Mysore (now Karnataka) on November 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: on November 1, 1956 it became a part of the new St-ate of Mysore  number Karnataka .

facts.text: Mysore Forest Act, 5 of 1964 enacted to consolidate law on forests.

anchor.surface_text: The Mysore legislature enacted the Mysore Forest Act, 5 of 1964, to companysolidate and amend the law relating to forests and forest produce in the State of Mysore.

facts.text: Mysore Forest Rules 1969 promulgated, including Rule 137 on redemption of trees in Bane lands.

anchor.surface_text: After the companymencement of that Act the Mysore Forest Rules were promulgated by the State Government in 1969. Rule 137 which is impugned by the appellants is in these terms

facts.text: Mysore Land Revenue Act, 12 of 1964 enacted on April 1, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: On April 1, 1964 the Mysore legislature enacted the Mysore Land Revenue Act, 12 of 1964,

facts.text: Section 75(1) of Mysore Land Revenue Act 1964 deems State right to trees ceded to occupant in survey settled villages unless reserved.

anchor.surface_text: Section 75 1  of the Land Revenue Act which has an important bearing on the case provides for the right to trees in villages in which survey settlement has been introduced.

facts.text: Original survey settlement in Nemmale village completed before April 1, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: the companymencement of this Act, the right of the State Government to all trees in any land, except trees reserved by the State Government or by any Survey Officer,

facts.text: High Court held Rule 10 contains express reservation of trees on Bane lands.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has held that Rule 10 of the Rules for Classifiers companytained in Appendix B to the Coorg Settlement Report, 1910 companytains an express reservation of the trees standing on Bane lands in favour of the State Government.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Rule 10 does not contain express order reserving State right to trees under Section 75(1).

anchor.surface_text: We find it difficult to agree that Rule 10 can be read as an express order reserving the right of the State Government to the trees, within the meaning of section 75 1  of the Mysore Land Revenue Act, 1964.

facts.text: Rule 137 of Mysore Forest Rules 1969 deleted by Karnataka Forest Amendment Rules 1973 notified January 15, 1974.

anchor.surface_text: That rule was deleted, during the pendency of this appeal, by the Karnataka Forest  Amendment  Rules, 1973 numberified on January 15, 1974.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside High Court judgment on construction of Rule 10 and relegates parties to other remedies due to inadequate record.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we set aside the judgment of the High Court on the companystruction of Rule 10 and since, apart from the validity of Rule 137 of the Mysore Forest Rules 1969, that is the only question decided by the High Court we allow the appeal.

issues.text: Whether the appellants are entitled to permit to cut and remove timber without payment of any timber value or whether they are liable to pay timber value for all trees without distinction between those existing in 1910 and later

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the appellants is that they are entitled to the permit to cut and remove the timber without payment of any timber value at all while the contention of the State Government is that nodistinction can be made as between trees existing in 1910 and those which came into existence later and therefore the appellants are liable to pay the timber value of the trees before being permitted to cut and remove the timber.

issues.text: Whether there is an express order made at or about the time of the original survey settlement by which the right to trees standing on Bane lands was reserved by the State Government or by any Survey Officer

anchor.surface_text: The first question which then arises is whether there is an express order made at or about the time of the original survey settlement by which the right to trees standing on Bane lands was reserved by the State Government or by any Survey Officer.

arguments.claim: Challenge to Rule 137 infructuous as deleted

anchor.surface_text: That rule was deleted, during the pendency of this appeal, by the Karnataka Forest  Amendment  Rules, 1973 notified on January 15, 1974. ... The only relief sought by the appellants has thus become infructuous.

holdings.text: The condition precedent to the application of section 75(1) of the Mysore Land Revenue Act, 1964 is satisfied as the original survey settlement in Nemmale village was completed before April 1, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The condition precedent to the application of section 75 1  is admittedly satisfied in this case because in regard to the village of Nemmale where the Bane lands of the 1st appellant are situated, the original survey settlement was completed before April 1, 1964 when the Mysore Land Revenue Act came into force.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Village had survey settlement before Act's commencement; no dispute on this fact.

holdings.text: Rule 10 of the Rules for Classifiers does not contain an express order reserving the right of the State Government to trees on Bane lands within the meaning of section 75(1) of the Mysore Land Revenue Act, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: We find it difficult to agree that Rule 10 can be read as an express order reserving the right of the State Government to the trees, within the meaning of section 75 1  of the Mysore Land Revenue Act, 1964.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 10 forms part of guidelines for classifiers implementing survey; describes historical rights, not substantive reservation order.

holdings.text: Rule 10 does not contain an express order reserving the right of the State Government to the trees growing on Bane lands, within the meaning of section 75(1) of the Mysore Land Revenue Act, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: That rule does not contain an express order reserving the right of the State Government to the trees growing on Bane lands, within the meaning of section 75 1  of the Mysore Land Revenue Act, 1964.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reaffirmation of interpretation; limits judgment to this issue only.

holdings.text: The challenge to Rule 137 of the Mysore Forest Rules, 1969 is infructuous as the rule was deleted during pendency of appeal.

anchor.surface_text: That rule was deleted, during the pendency of this appeal, by the Karnataka Forest Amendment Rules, 1973 notified on January 15, 1974.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deletion by amendment renders relief sought academic; no need to decide validity.

holdings.text: The only relief sought by the appellants has become infructuous due to deletion of Rule 137.

anchor.surface_text: The only relief sought by the appellants has thus become infructuous.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Writ petition solely sought quashing of Rule 137; deletion eliminates controversy.

holdings.text: High Court judgment on construction of Rule 10 set aside; appeal allowed.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we set aside the judgment of the High Court on the construction of Rule 10 and since, apart from the validity of Rule 137 of the Mysore Forest Rules 1969, that is the only question decided by the High Court we allow the appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred in interpreting Rule 10 as reservation; other issues not decided due to inadequate record.

holdings.text: No material on record to decide contentions except construction of Rule 10.

anchor.surface_text: In the present state of the record it is not possible to entertain and examine the submissions of the Advocate-General.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Writ petition and counter inadequate; parties must pursue other remedies.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances of the case there will be no order as costs.

justification_sets.label: Section 75(1) Mysore Land Revenue Act 1964 support

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we set aside the judgment of the High Court on the companystruction of Rule 10 and since, apart from the validity of Rule 137 of the Mysore Forest Rules 1969, that is the only question decided by the High Court we allow the appeal.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; judgment of High Court set aside insofar as construction of Rule 10; other issues not decided as Rule 137 deleted and original relief infructuous; parties relegated to pursue alternative remedies.
directions: Parties will be at liberty to agitate the other questions in such proceedings as they may be advised to take.
